claim: Cell- and egg-based flu vaccines have the potential to develop mutations during production, which may reduce their effectiveness.
explanation: Four-panel figure showing geometric mean fold rise of microneutralization (MN) or hemagglutination inhibition (HI) antibody titers at 1 month post‐vaccination (panels A and B) and geometric mean fold reduction of antibody titers at 6 months post‐vaccination (panels C and D) in two age groups (18–44 years and 45–64 years). Each plot compares responses against egg‐propagated versus cell‐propagated influenza virus antigens for four vaccine formulations (Fluzone IIV4, Fluarix IIV4, ccIIV4, RIV4) across multiple viral strains (H3N2, H1N1, B/Victoria, B/Yamagata). P-values indicate statistical comparisons between vaccines and antigen propagation methods. The figure reports immunogenicity differences against egg‐ and cell‐propagated antigens but does not present data on production‐induced mutations or their impact on vaccine effectiveness, and therefore does not support the claim.
